children.name: it’ll cost you
children.definition: it’s going to cost you//ɪts ˌgəʊɪŋ tə ˈkɒst juː, ɪtl ˈkɒst juːǁ-ˈkɔːst-/ spoken informal if you say it’s going to cost you or it’ll cost you when someone wants to buy something, you mean it will be expensive for them:
examples: ▪ You can get new parts specially made for these, but it’ll cost you.
▪ There are some places that can mend the suit in a couple of hours, but it’s going to cost you.

children.name: not come cheap
children.definition: /nɒt kʌm ˈtʃiːp/  informal to be expensive - use this especially when you think that even though something is expensive, it is still worth buying:
examples: ▪ Gibson guitars sound great, but they don’t come cheap.
▪ It would be great if we could hire her, but with all her experience, she won’t come cheap.

children.name: pricey
children.definition: /ˈpraɪsi/  informal very expensive or too expensive - use this especially when you are deciding whether or not to buy something:
examples: ▪ Let’s not eat here - it’s too pricey.
▪ The tickets were kind of pricey, but the show was good.

children.name: expensive
children.definition: /ɪkˈspensɪv/  an expensive hotel, restaurant, area etc is very fashionable and it is expensive to stay, eat, or live there:
examples: ▪ My uncle took us out to dinner at an expensive restaurant.
▪ The house is on West Boston Avenue, Detroit’s most expensive residential area.

children.name: exclusive
children.definition: /ɪkˈskluːsɪv/  an exclusivearea,school,shop,clubetcis very expensive, and only a few very rich people have enough money to live there or use it:
examples: đặc biệt dành cho người giàu ...
▪ They live in Bel Air, an exclusive suburb of Los Angeles.
▪ The country club is very exclusive - you have to be invited to join.
exclusiveadjective độc
expensive and only for people who are rich or of a high social class
_an exclusive private club
_an exclusive part of town

children.name: luxurious
children.definition: /lʌgˈzjʊəriəs, ləgˈʒʊəriəsǁləgˈʒʊəriəs/  a luxuriousbuildingorroomis large, very comfortable, and has expensive decorations and furniture:
examples: xa hoa
▪ a room in a luxurious New York hotel
▪ Atlantis is one of the world’s most luxurious cruise ships.
luxuriousadjective sang trọng, lộng lẫy; xa hoa
very comfortable and expensive
_They have a very luxurious house.
_We spent a luxurious weekend at a country hotel.

children.name: fancy
children.definition: độc
examples: fancy/ˈfænsi/ [adjective] especially American,spokena fancy house, car, hotel, restaurant etc is expensive and fashionable:
▪ You’d think a fancy restaurant like this would have better service.
▪ We stayed in a fancy Victorian hotel in San Francisco.

children.name: posh
children.definition: /pɒʃǁpɑːʃ/  especially British,spokena posh restaurant, house, car etc is expensive and looks as if it is used or owned by rich people:
examples: sang trọng
▪ When I’m famous I’m going to stay in a posh hotel and drink champagne all day.
▪ She goes to a posh girls’ school near Brighton.
poshadjective
informal(of places and things) expensive and of high quality
_He takes her to some really posh restaurants.

children.name: upmarket
children.definition: especially British /upscaleAmerican /ˌʌpˈmɑːʳkɪt◂, ˌʌpˈmɑːʳkət◂ǁˈʌpskeɪl/  used or bought by people who belong to a higher social class or have more money than ordinary people, and therefore more expensive:
examples: ▪ I was surprised when I saw her apartment - I’d have expected a lawyer to have something a little more upmarket.
▪ New upscale shops and restaurants are driving some of the older businesses out of the neighborhood.

children.name: classy
children.definition: /ˈklɑːsiǁˈklæsi/  fashionable, expensive, and used by people who have a lot of money or belong to a high social class:
examples: ▪ She took us to a very classy seafood restaurant in the old part of the city.
▪ The cafe’s interior has been redone and looks very classy.
▪ The Grand Union Hotel is one of the classiest hotels in this part of the country.

children.name: plush
children.definition: /plʌʃ/ plush hotel/office/apartment etca hotel, office etc that looks expensive because it contains a lot of nice furniture, decorations etc:
examples: ▪ The firm’s headquarters is a plush $2.5 million office building on Woodside Road.
▪ the plush lobby of a four-star hotel

children.name: be a rip-off
children.definition: /biː ə ˈrɪp ɒf/ spokeninformalyou say something is a rip-off when you think someone isunfairlycharging too much money for it:
examples: ▪ Eighty dollars for a pair of jeans? What a rip-off!
a complete/total rip-off
▪ The vacation package we bought ended up being a total rip-off.

children.name: can’t afford
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt əˈfɔːʳdǁˌkænt-/  if you can’t afford something, you do not have enough money to buy it or pay for it:
examples: ▪ I really need a new coat, but I can’t afford one.
can’t afford to do something
▪ We couldn’t afford to go on holiday last year.
can’t afford it
▪ Hiring a lawyer would be expensive, and she just couldn’t afford it.

children.name: exorbitant/extortionate
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɔːʳbɪtənt, ɪgˈzɔːʳbətənt, ɪkˈstɔːʳʃənt/ prices,charges,rentsetc that are exorbitant or extortionate, are very much higher than they should be, and you think they areunfair:
examples: quá đắt, cắt cổ
▪ The restaurant charges exorbitant prices for very ordinary food.
▪ Interest rates for some of the credit cards are extortionate.

children.name: prohibitive/prohibitively expensive
children.definition: /prəˈhɪbɪtɪv, prəˈhɪbətɪv, prəˌhɪbtɪvli ɪkˈspensɪvǁprəʊ-/  prices or costs that are prohibitive or prohibitively expensive are so high that people cannot pay them or decide not to pay them because they are too expensive:
examples: ▪ For most people, the cost of living in the centre of town is prohibitive.
▪ The computer was superior to other models, but it was prohibitively expensive.

children.name: inflated prices
children.definition: /ɪnˌfleɪtɪd ˈpraɪsəz, ɪnˌfleɪtəd ˈpraɪsəz/  prices that are much higher than usual and much higher than they should be, so that the person who charges them can make a big profit:
examples: ▪ Nightclubs often charge inflated prices for drinks.
at inflated prices
▪ Some people buy large blocks of tickets and then try to sell them at vastly inflated prices.

children.name: steep
children.definition: /stiːp/ informalprices, charges, rents etc that are steep seem unusually or surprisingly high:
examples: ▪ I think £7 for a drink is a bit steep, don’t you?
▪ It’s hard to find an apartment around here, and when you do the rents are pretty steep.

children.name: be daylight robbery
children.definition: British /be highway robberyAmerican /biː ˌdeɪlaɪt ˈrɒbəri, biː ˌhaɪweɪ ˈrɒbəriǁ-ˈrɑː-/  informal if you say that a price or charge is daylight robbery or highway robbery you mean it is very much higher than it should be:
examples: ▪ I’m not paying £5 for an ice-cream - that’s daylight robbery!
▪ We knew it was highway robbery, but we had no choice but to pay.

children.name: price sth out of the market
children.definition: price something out of the market/ˌpraɪs something aʊt əv, ðə ˈmɑːʳkt/  to make something so expensive that people will no longer buy it because they can buy something similar at a lower price:
examples: be priced out of the market
▪ British electrical equipment is likely to be priced out of the market by cheap imports.
price yourself out of the market
▪ Ford don’t want to raise its prices any more - it’s worried about pricing itself out of the market.

children.name: valuable
children.definition: /ˈvæljuəbəl, -jɑbəlǁˈvæljɑbəl/  worth a lot of money and expensive to buy or replace:
examples: có giá trị lớn, quý giá
▪ Don’t lose this ring -- it’s very valuable.
▪ Besides her studio apartment, she also owns a valuable estate in Italy.
▪ Rogers had purchased a valuable Hebrew manuscript from a dealer in Jerusalem.
valuableadjectiveMONEY quý giá; có giá trị nhiều tiền
worth a lot of money
_These antiques are extremely valuable.
_This is losing valuable business for the company.

children.name: of great value
children.definition: /əv ˌgreɪt ˈvæljuː/  something that is of great value is worth a lot of money, especially a personal possession such as a work of art or a piece of jewellery:
examples: ▪ He has a few medals of great value.
▪ The burglars stole the television and video, but nothing of great value.

children.name: be worth a lot
children.definition: /biː ˌwɜːʳθ ə ˈlɒtǁ-ˈlɑːt/ informalif something is worth a lot, you can get a lot of money if you sell it:
examples: rất có giá
▪ You should look after those old dolls - one day they could be worth a lot.

children.name: be worth a fortune
children.definition: /biː ˌwɜːʳθ ə ˈfɔːʳtʃən/  if something is worth a fortune it is worth a very large amount of money:
examples: đáng giá cả gia tài
▪ He was very poor when he died, but now his paintings are worth a fortune.

children.name: precious
children.definition: /ˈpreʃəs/  preciousmetal/stonea valuable metal such as gold or a jewel such as a diamond:
examples: quý
▪ The robe was encrusted with precious metals and stones.
preciousadjectiveVALUABLE
of great value because of being rare, expensive or important
_a precious gift
_a precious moment/memory
_Clean water is a precious commodity in many parts of the world.
_You're so precioustome.

children.name: priceless
children.definition: /ˈpraɪsləs/  worth so much money that it is impossible to calculate the price - use this about objects that areoldandraresuch as paintings, furniture, or jewellery:
examples: vô giá
▪ The house was full of priceless antiques.
▪ a priceless oil painting
pricelessadjective uy tín
describes an object which has such a high value, especially because it is rare, that the price of it cannot be calculated
_A priceless collection of vases was destroyed.
_figurativeHer knowledge and experience would make her a priceless (= extremely useful) asset to the team.

children.name: cost a fortune
children.definition: /ˌkɒst ə ˈfɔʳːtʃənǁˌkɔːst/  especiallyspoken,informalif something costs a fortune, it is very expensive:
examples: đáng giá cả gia tài
▪ What a beautiful car - it must have cost a fortune.
cost somebody a fortune
▪ We had to eat out every night - it ended up costing us a fortune.
cost a fortune to do something
▪ It’ll cost a fortune to get that old car of his repaired.
cost an absolute fortune
▪ The hotel was great, but it cost an absolute fortune.

children.name: cost a bomb/the earth
children.definition: /ˌkɒst ə ˈbɒm, ði ˈɜːʳθǁˌkɔːst ə ˈbɑːm-/  British informal to be very expensive:
examples: ▪ I can’t imagine how she affords to send her kids to that school - it must cost a bomb.
▪ Good shoes needn’t cost the earth.
cost somebody a bomb/the earth
▪ The divorce cost me a bomb.

children.name: cost an arm and a leg
children.definition: /kɒst ən ˌɑːʳm ənd ə legǁkɔːst-/  spoken to be very expensive:
examples: ▪ That carpet must have cost an arm and a leg.
cost somebody an arm and a leg
▪ Getting good health insurance these days costs an arm and a leg.

children.name: luxury
children.definition: noun hàng xa xỉ; xa xỉ phẩm
examples: [ C ] something expensive which is pleasant to have but is not necessary
_luxuries, such as champagne and chocolate
_I like to buy myselflittleluxuries from time to time.

children.name: luxury
children.definition: noun hàng xa xỉ; xa xỉ phẩm
examples: [ S or U ] something which gives you a lot of pleasure but which you cannot often do
_A day off work is such a luxury.

children.name: luxury
children.definition: noun sự xa xỉ, sự xa hoa
examples: [ U ] great comfort, especially as provided by expensive and beautiful things
_to live in luxury
_a luxury cruise
_a luxury hotel

children.name: grand
children.definition: adjectiveSPLENDID
examples: splendid in style and appearance; attracting admiration and attention
_ThePalaceofVersaillesis very grand.
_They always entertain their guestsingrandstyle.

children.name: dear
children.definition: /dɪəʳ/  British expensive - use this especially about things you buy inshops:
examples: ▪ Those strawberries look a bit dear.
▪ The blue jacket is slightly dearer, but it’s much better material.
▪ No, you can’t have an ice-cream - they’re too dear.

children.name: expensive
children.definition: /ɪkˈspensɪv/  something that is expensive costs a lot of money, more than other things of the same type:
examples: ▪ She spends most of her money on expensive clothes.
▪ Do you have any less expensive cameras?
▪ Taxis are so expensive - that’s why I usually take the bus.
expensive to make/run/buy etc
▪ Movies are incredibly expensive to make these days.
expensiveadjective đắt tiền
costing a lot of money
_Rolls Royces are very expensive.
_Big houses are expensivetomaintain.
_She has expensivetastes(= she likes things that cost a lot of money) .

children.name: costly
children.definition: /ˈkɒstliǁˈkɔːstli/  a plan, activity etc that is costly is too expensive and wastes money - used especially about plans carried out by governments or companies:
examples: ▪ The finance committee rejected their plan because they said it was too costly.
▪ Caring for the park’s swans is a costly business - roughly $26,600 per year.
costly mistake
▪ Buying all those computers was a costly mistake.

children.name: high
children.definition: /haɪ/  if thepriceorcostof something is high, it costs a lot:
examples: ▪ Rents in central London are very high.
▪ The cost of living is higher in Denmark than in Germany.
▪ Increased production costs will mean higher prices for consumers.

children.name: cost a lot
children.definition: (of money)/ˌkɒst ə ˌlɒt (əv ˈmʌni)ǁˌkɔːst ə ˈlɑːt/  especiallyspokenif something, especially somethingyou do, costs a lot it is expensive:
examples: ▪ I managed to find the bike I wanted but it cost a lot.
▪ It costs a lot of money to go to medical school, you know.
cost a lot (of money) to do something
▪ Did it cost a lot to fly to Rio?
